thread.title: Portland Timbers make major playoff push with 1-0 win against Real Salt Lake
thread.title_full: Portland Timbers make major playoff push with 1-0 win against Real Salt Lake | OregonLive.com

author: Molly Blue | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Portland Timbers make major playoff push with 1-0 win against Real Salt Lake
text:
Portland Timbers coach Caleb Porter gambled with a new-look, attack-heavy lineup in a must-win road game with a spot in the Western Conference playoffs at stake.
It paid off.
In his 100th game as Portland's head coach, Porter and the Timbers got their most important win of the season, defeating Real Salt Lake 1-0 at Rio Tinto Stadium in Sandy, Utah on Wednesday.
Portland (13-11-8, 47 points) scored when Fanendo Adi converted a penalty kick in the 54th minute, catching RSL goalkeeper Nick Rimando guessing the wrong way.
"That's the game," Adi said in a television interview after the game. "I felt very comfortable."
Timbers forward Lucas Melano drew the penalty when he got behind Real Salt Lake's defense in the 53rd minute, was tripped up by Jamison Olave and went down. Olave was shown a red card, sent off and the home team finished with 10 players.
Melano was back defending against a Salt Lake corner kick when he suffered an apparent shoulder injury when he went up for a ball against Justen Glad; he eventually came off in favor of George Fochive as the Timbers assumed a more defensive look in the final 27 minutes.
Portland goalkeeper Adam Kwarasey earned his 13th clean sheet of the season and had two significant saves near the end of the game -- one in stoppage time off of a deflection -- to preserve the win.
With the victory, the Timbers move above the red line -- into a fifth-place tie with the Seattle Sounders at the moment -- and put themselves in a much better position to slide into the Western Conference playoffs. They've been vying with Real Salt Lake (11-13-8, 41 points) and the San Jose Earthquakes (12-12-8, 44) in the last couple of weeks as Major League Soccer's regular season winds down.
In their two previous league games this season, Salt Lake and Portland played to a 0-0 draw and the Timbers won 1-0.
That may be why, for this match, Porter crafted a starting lineup with a go-for-broke offense. For the first time this season, the top of the formation was Melano Adi, Darlington Nagbe , Rodney Wallace and Diego Valeri , with Diego Chara the lone defensive midfielder.
"Sometimes you get it right," Porter said. "The players deserve all the credit.
"In the first half, we came out aggressive, we came out to attack," Porter added. "Obviously, our lineup and game plan reflected that."
The Timbers' scoring woes have been well chronicled this season and this attack packed a punch.
The Timbers have two games remaining â€” Sunday at the second-place LA Galaxy and on Oct. 25 at home against the last-place Colorado Rapids at Providence Park.
Portland will have to go without Alvas Powell against the the Galaxy. He's suspended on a yellow-card accumulation after he was booked in the 28th minute against Salt Lake. LA have already clinched a playoff spot but are still in the hunt for the Supporters Shield.
